papers.title: User Experience in Modern Cars – Definition, Relevance and Challenges of Digital Automotive Applications
definitions: User experience (UX) encompasses all aspects of how people interact with a product, including how it feels, how well they understand it, their emotional response while using it, its utility, and its contextual fit (Alben, 1996).

In UX research, subjective criteria and individual experiences with the product take precedence over objective usability criteria. Alben, 1996, emphasizes the importance of subjective criteria in understanding user experience.

According to Hassenzahl, 2010, user experience involves pragmatic and hedonic qualities. Pragmatic UX focuses on practicality and goal orientation, while hedonic UX emphasizes fun and entertainment. Both perspectives contribute to a comprehensive understanding of user experience.
references: Hassenzahl, Marc. (2010) “Experience design: Technology for all the right reasons”in: Synthesis Lectures on Human-Centered Informatics Volume 3 No. 1.
Alben, Lauralee. (1996). Defining the Criteria for Effective Interaction Design

papers.title: FROM THE DEFINITION OF USER EXPERIENCE TO AFRAMEWORK TO CLASSIFY ITS APPLICATIONS IN DESIGN
definitions: User experience (UX) encompasses the emotional and affective aspects of interaction, emphasizing the 'joy to own' a product or system (Sun and Teng, 2017).

According to Hassenzahl and Tractinsky (2006), UX is a combination of factors involving the user (e.g., predispositions, expectations, needs, motivation, and mood), the designed system (e.g., complexity, purpose, usability, and functionality), and the context of interaction.
Scholars like McCarthy and Wright (2004) interpret human interaction with technology as a multi-dimensional experience, comprising sensual, emotional, compositional, and spatio-temporal aspects.
Contrary to some views, Hassenzahl (2010) argues that technology and interactive products mediate but do not constitute experiences themselves.

ISO 9241-210 defines UX as 'a person's perceptions and responses resulting from the use or anticipated use of a product, system, or service' (DIS, 2010), encapsulating users' emotions, beliefs, preferences, perceptions, and behaviors.
references: DIS, I. (2010), “9241-210: 2010. Ergonomics of human system interaction-Part 210: Human-centred design forinteractive systems (formerly known as 13407)”, International Standardization Organization (ISO).
Hassenzahl, M. (2010), “Experience Design: Technology for All the Right Reasons”, Synthesis Lectures onHuman-Centered Informatics, Vol. 3 No. 1, pp. 1–95
McCarthy, J. and Wright, P. (2004), Technology as Experience, Vol. 11, MIT Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts,United States.
Hassenzahl, M. and Tractinsky, N. (2006), “User experience - a research agenda”, Behaviour & InformationTechnology, Vol. 25 No. 2, pp. 91–97.

Sun, S. and Teng, L. (2017), “Establishing China’s First UX Master Program Based on Applied PsychologyPerspective”, in Marcus, A. and Wang, W. (Eds.), Design, User Experience, and Usability: Theory,Methodology, and Management, Springer International Publishing, Cham, pp. 767–775

papers.title: DEFINITIONS AND CONCEPTS OF USER EXPERIENCE (UX): A LITERATURE REVIEW
definitions: User experience (UX) in human-computer interaction involves individual perception, emotion, cognition, motivation, and action, encompassing interaction with various elements (Kuliga et al., 2015).

UX is about understanding how individuals derive value from their interactions with products, systems, or experiences, emphasizing credibility, desirability, usefulness, and usability (Pietroni et al., 2016).
Simonsen (2018) defines UX as the user's emotional and evaluative responses while interacting with a user interface (UI), focusing on achieving goals, aesthetics, and user perception.
ISO9241-210 characterizes UX as the perceptions and responses of humans resulting from the anticipation or use of products, systems, or services (Han et al., 2017).
UX encompasses usability but extends beyond it to include satisfaction, affect, and user value, as proposed by Park et al. (2011), indicating the subjective nature of UX (Zarour & Alharbi, 2017).
references: Kuliga, S. F., Thrash, T., Dalton, R. C., & Hölscher, C. (2015). Computers, Environment and Urban Systems Virtual Reality as An Empirical Research Tool—Exploring User Experience in A Real Building and A Corresponding Virtual Model. CEUS, 54, 363–375

Pietroni, E., Pagano, A., Amadei, M., & Galiffa, F. (2016). Livia,s Villa Reloaded Virtual Reality Museum: User Experience Evaluation. ICERI2016 Proceedings, 349–359. https://doi.org/10.21125/iceri.2016.1083
Simonsen, J. G. (2018). Evaluation Factors User Experience. The Wiley Handbook of Human Computer Interaction, Volume 1(1st Edition), 193–206.

Park, J., Han, S. H., Kim, H. K., Cho, Y., & Park, W. (2011). Developing Elements of User Experience for Mobile Phones and Services: Survey, Interview, and Observation Approaches. Human Factors and Ergonomics in Manufacturing & Service Industries, 00(0), 1–15

papers.title: Experiências Arquitetônicas: Propostas de abordagem de projeto com enfoque na produção intencional de experiência do usuário na arquitetura
definitions: Atmosfera arquitetônica, também conhecida como Atmosfera afetiva, faz referência ao mood, qualidades sensoriais e sensações transmitidas por um determinado espaço arquitetônico (MATHEW, 2017).
Atmosfera é a impressão sensorial e emocional de um determinado espaço, local ou situação social (PALLASMAA, 2014).

A Atmosfera é compreendida como um todo. Não se trata, portanto, de algo determinístico, que pode ser dividido em partes, mas sim da percepção que se tem de um espaço como um todo quando se é exposto ao mesmo (MERLEAU-PONTY, 1962).

Atmosfera é a arquitetura, e em um contexto de pós-materialismo como para o qual a humanidade está caminhando, é preciso que arquitetos passem a dar mais ênfase nos aspectos sensoriais e emocionais dos espaços que projetam (RAHM, 2018).

Atmosferas são compostas do corpo da arquitetura (sua materialidade), da consonância dos materiais, dos sons dos espaços, da temperatura dos espaços, do entorno, do contraste, da luz, dos graus de intimidade, da harmonia, da forma bonita e da ‘envolvência’ da arquitetura (ZUMTHOR, 2006).
references: Pallasmaa, J. 'Space, place and atmosphere: Emotion and peripherical perception in architectural experience.' Lebenswelt: aesthetics and philosophy of experience, n.4, p. 230-245, 2014.
MERLEAU-PONTY, M. Phenomenology of Perception: an introduction. Routledge, 1962.
Rahm, P. Philippe Rahm Architectes. Architectural Climates. Lars Muller Publishers, 2018.
